content: I'm not really sure if it's bug or feature, but I just found that \sim transforms into ∼, which is different from ~. I found this when I was trying to write ~[Filter.atBot] and obtaining uninformative "expected token" error messages. I'm curious if ∼ is used somewhere, because \sim is the way most people encode asymptotic equivalence in LaTeX.
It looks like it's used in one place at least, in Mathlib.ModelTheory.Order as FirstOrder.Language.BoundedFormula.not
I think you should ask this in #mathlib4 possibly.
Maybe we should add priority := 1 notations for these "false friends" that emit an error telling you want to type instead
(the low priority would still allow downstream code to override the notation if it really wanted to)

I think we should have a "full" unicode linter, e.g., one that uses a whitelist. Allowing all unicode is likely to cause headaches long-term (since unicode is such an untamable beast). I tried to argue for it in this discussion.

If anyone is interested, I'd also try to help implement it, though one would probably need a lot of community opinions before implementing anything that has a chance of being adopted. It seemed as though my opinion that this is a good idea is a minority one, however.
An alternative would be for Lean itself to emit "did you mean..." messages for visually similar unicode characters if the one typed gives an error and an alternative does not
